types.description:
Update documents.
Updates documents that match the specified query.
If no query is specified, performs an update on every document in the data stream or index without modifying the source, which is useful for picking up mapping changes.

path.description:
Comma-separated list of data streams, indices, and aliases to search.
Supports wildcards (`*`).
To search all data streams or indices, omit this parameter or use `*` or `_all`.
path.name: index

query.description:
If `false`, the request returns an error if any wildcard expression, index alias, or `_all` value targets only missing or closed indices.
This behavior applies even if the request targets other open indices.
For example, a request targeting `foo*,bar*` returns an error if an index starts with `foo` but no index starts with `bar`.
query.name: allow_no_indices

query.description: Analyzer to use for the query string.
query.name: analyzer

query.description: If `true`, wildcard and prefix queries are analyzed.
query.name: analyze_wildcard

query.description: What to do if update by query hits version conflicts: `abort` or `proceed`.
query.name: conflicts

query.description: The default operator for query string query: `AND` or `OR`.
query.name: default_operator

query.description: Field to use as default where no field prefix is given in the query string.
query.name: df

query.description:
Type of index that wildcard patterns can match.
If the request can target data streams, this argument determines whether wildcard expressions match hidden data streams.
Supports comma-separated values, such as `open,hidden`.
Valid values are: `all`, `open`, `closed`, `hidden`, `none`.
query.name: expand_wildcards

query.description: Starting offset (default: 0)
query.name: from

query.description: If `false`, the request returns an error if it targets a missing or closed index.
query.name: ignore_unavailable

query.description: If `true`, format-based query failures (such as providing text to a numeric field) in the query string will be ignored.
query.name: lenient

query.description:
Maximum number of documents to process.
Defaults to all documents.
query.name: max_docs

query.description:
ID of the pipeline to use to preprocess incoming documents.
If the index has a default ingest pipeline specified, then setting the value to `_none` disables the default ingest pipeline for this request.
If a final pipeline is configured it will always run, regardless of the value of this parameter.
query.name: pipeline

query.description:
Specifies the node or shard the operation should be performed on.
Random by default.
query.name: preference

query.description: Query in the Lucene query string syntax.
query.name: q

query.description: If `true`, Elasticsearch refreshes affected shards to make the operation visible to search.
query.name: refresh

query.description: If `true`, the request cache is used for this request.
query.name: request_cache

query.description: The throttle for this request in sub-requests per second.
query.name: requests_per_second

query.description: Custom value used to route operations to a specific shard.
query.name: routing

query.description: Period to retain the search context for scrolling.
query.name: scroll

query.description: Size of the scroll request that powers the operation.
query.name: scroll_size

query.description: Explicit timeout for each search request.
query.name: search_timeout

query.description: The type of the search operation. Available options: `query_then_fetch`, `dfs_query_then_fetch`.
query.name: search_type

query.description: The number of slices this task should be divided into.
query.name: slices

query.description: A comma-separated list of <field>:<direction> pairs.
query.name: sort

query.description: Specific `tag` of the request for logging and statistical purposes.
query.name: stats

query.description:
Maximum number of documents to collect for each shard.
If a query reaches this limit, Elasticsearch terminates the query early.
Elasticsearch collects documents before sorting.
Use with caution.
Elasticsearch applies this parameter to each shard handling the request.
When possible, let Elasticsearch perform early termination automatically.
Avoid specifying this parameter for requests that target data streams with backing indices across multiple data tiers.
query.name: terminate_after

query.description: Period each update request waits for the following operations: dynamic mapping updates, waiting for active shards.
query.name: timeout

query.description: If `true`, returns the document version as part of a hit.
query.name: version

query.description: Should the document increment the version number (internal) on hit or not (reindex)
query.name: version_type

query.description:
The number of shard copies that must be active before proceeding with the operation.
Set to `all` or any positive integer up to the total number of shards in the index (`number_of_replicas+1`).
query.name: wait_for_active_shards

query.description: If `true`, the request blocks until the operation is complete.
query.name: wait_for_completion

types.description:
Cause and details about a request failure. This class defines the properties common to all error types.
Additional details are also provided, that depend on the error type.

properties.description: The type of error
properties.name: type

properties.description: A human-readable explanation of the error, in english
properties.name: reason

properties.description: The server stack trace. Present only if the `error_trace=true` parameter was sent with the request.
properties.name: stack_trace

types.description:
In some places in the specification an object consists of the union of a set of known properties
and a set of runtime injected properties. Meaning that object should theoretically extend Dictionary but expose
a set of known keys and possibly. The object might already be part of an object graph and have a parent class.
This puts it into a bind that needs a client specific solution.
We therefore document the requirement to behave like a dictionary for unknown properties with this interface.
Contains parameters used to limit or change the subsequent search body request.

members.description: Match any data stream or index, including hidden ones.
members.name: all

members.description: Match open, non-hidden indices. Also matches any non-hidden data stream.
members.name: open

members.description: Match closed, non-hidden indices. Also matches any non-hidden data stream. Data streams cannot be closed.
members.name: closed

members.description: Match hidden data streams and hidden indices. Must be combined with open, closed, or both.
members.name: hidden

members.description: Wildcard expressions are not accepted.
members.name: none

members.description: Documents are scored using local term and document frequencies for the shard. This is usually faster but less accurate.
members.name: query_then_fetch

members.description: Documents are scored using global term and document frequencies across all shards. This is usually slower but more accurate.
members.name: dfs_query_then_fetch

properties.description: Defines the search definition using the Query DSL.
properties.name: query

properties.description: If true, returns detailed information about score computation as part of a hit.
properties.name: explain

properties.description: Configuration of search extensions defined by Elasticsearch plugins.
properties.name: ext

properties.description:
List of stored fields to return as part of a hit. If no fields are specified,
no stored fields are included in the response. If this field is specified, the _source
parameter defaults to false. You can pass _source: true to return both source fields
and stored fields in the search response.
properties.name: stored_fields

properties.description:
Array of wildcard (*) patterns. The request returns doc values for field
names matching these patterns in the hits.fields property of the response.
properties.name: docvalue_fields

properties.description: Defines the approximate kNN search to run.
properties.name: knn

properties.description:
Starting document offset. By default, you cannot page through more than 10,000
hits using the from and size parameters. To page through more hits, use the
search_after parameter.
properties.name: from

properties.description: Boosts the _score of documents from specified indices.
properties.name: indices_boost

properties.description:
Minimum _score for matching documents. Documents with a lower _score are
not included in the search results.
properties.name: min_score

properties.description: Retrieve a script evaluation (based on different fields) for each hit.
properties.name: script_fields

properties.description:
The number of hits to return. By default, you cannot page through more
than 10,000 hits using the from and size parameters. To page through more
hits, use the search_after parameter.
properties.name: size

properties.description:
Indicates which source fields are returned for matching documents. These
fields are returned in the hits._source property of the search response.
properties.name: _source

properties.description:
Array of wildcard (*) patterns. The request returns values for field names
matching these patterns in the hits.fields property of the response.
properties.name: fields

properties.description:
Maximum number of documents to collect for each shard. If a query reaches this
limit, Elasticsearch terminates the query early. Elasticsearch collects documents
before sorting. Defaults to 0, which does not terminate query execution early.
properties.name: terminate_after

properties.description:
Stats groups to associate with the search. Each group maintains a statistics
aggregation for its associated searches. You can retrieve these stats using
the indices stats API.
properties.name: stats

properties.description:
Specifies the period of time to wait for a response from each shard. If no response
is received before the timeout expires, the request fails and returns an error.
Defaults to no timeout.
properties.name: timeout

properties.description: If true, calculate and return document scores, even if the scores are not used for sorting.
properties.name: track_scores

properties.description:
Number of hits matching the query to count accurately. If true, the exact
number of hits is returned at the cost of some performance. If false, the
response does not include the total number of hits matching the query.
Defaults to 10,000 hits.
properties.name: track_total_hits

properties.description: If true, returns document version as part of a hit.
properties.name: version

properties.description:
Defines one or more runtime fields in the search request. These fields take
precedence over mapped fields with the same name.
properties.name: runtime_mappings

properties.description:
If true, returns sequence number and primary term of the last modification
of each hit. See Optimistic concurrency control.
properties.name: seq_no_primary_term

properties.description:
Limits the search to a point in time (PIT). If you provide a PIT, you
cannot specify an <index> in the request path.
properties.name: pit

properties.description:
Sub-aggregations for this aggregation.
Only applies to bucket aggregations.
properties.name: aggregations

properties.description:
A bucket aggregation returning a form of adjacency matrix.
The request provides a collection of named filter expressions, similar to the `filters` aggregation.
Each bucket in the response represents a non-empty cell in the matrix of intersecting filters.
properties.name: adjacency_matrix

properties.description: A multi-bucket aggregation similar to the date histogram, except instead of providing an interval to use as the width of each bucket, a target number of buckets is provided.
properties.name: auto_date_histogram

properties.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that computes the average of numeric values that are extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: avg

properties.description:
A sibling pipeline aggregation which calculates the mean value of a specified metric in a sibling aggregation.
The specified metric must be numeric and the sibling aggregation must be a multi-bucket aggregation.
properties.name: avg_bucket

properties.description: A metrics aggregation that computes a box plot of numeric values extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: boxplot

properties.description: A parent pipeline aggregation which runs a script which can perform per bucket computations on metrics in the parent multi-bucket aggregation.
properties.name: bucket_script

properties.description: A parent pipeline aggregation which runs a script to determine whether the current bucket will be retained in the parent multi-bucket aggregation.
properties.name: bucket_selector

properties.description: A parent pipeline aggregation which sorts the buckets of its parent multi-bucket aggregation.
properties.name: bucket_sort

properties.description: A sibling pipeline aggregation which runs a two sample Kolmogorov–Smirnov test ("K-S test") against a provided distribution and the distribution implied by the documents counts in the configured sibling aggregation.
properties.name: bucket_count_ks_test

properties.description: A sibling pipeline aggregation which runs a correlation function on the configured sibling multi-bucket aggregation.
properties.name: bucket_correlation

properties.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that calculates an approximate count of distinct values.
properties.name: cardinality

properties.description: A multi-bucket aggregation that groups semi-structured text into buckets.
properties.name: categorize_text

properties.description: A single bucket aggregation that selects child documents that have the specified type, as defined in a `join` field.
properties.name: children

properties.description:
A multi-bucket aggregation that creates composite buckets from different sources.
Unlike the other multi-bucket aggregations, you can use the `composite` aggregation to paginate *all* buckets from a multi-level aggregation efficiently.
properties.name: composite

properties.description: A parent pipeline aggregation which calculates the cumulative cardinality in a parent `histogram` or `date_histogram` aggregation.
properties.name: cumulative_cardinality

properties.description: A parent pipeline aggregation which calculates the cumulative sum of a specified metric in a parent `histogram` or `date_histogram` aggregation.
properties.name: cumulative_sum

properties.description:
A multi-bucket values source based aggregation that can be applied on date values or date range values extracted from the documents.
It dynamically builds fixed size (interval) buckets over the values.
properties.name: date_histogram

properties.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation that enables the user to define a set of date ranges - each representing a bucket.
properties.name: date_range

properties.description: A parent pipeline aggregation which calculates the derivative of a specified metric in a parent `histogram` or `date_histogram` aggregation.
properties.name: derivative

properties.description:
A filtering aggregation used to limit any sub aggregations' processing to a sample of the top-scoring documents.
Similar to the `sampler` aggregation, but adds the ability to limit the number of matches that share a common value.
properties.name: diversified_sampler

properties.description: A multi-value metrics aggregation that computes stats over numeric values extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: extended_stats

properties.description: A sibling pipeline aggregation which calculates a variety of stats across all bucket of a specified metric in a sibling aggregation.
properties.name: extended_stats_bucket

properties.description: A bucket aggregation which finds frequent item sets, a form of association rules mining that identifies items that often occur together.
properties.name: frequent_item_sets

properties.description: A single bucket aggregation that narrows the set of documents to those that match a query.
properties.name: filter

properties.description: A multi-bucket aggregation where each bucket contains the documents that match a query.
properties.name: filters

properties.description: A metric aggregation that computes the geographic bounding box containing all values for a Geopoint or Geoshape field.
properties.name: geo_bounds

properties.description: A metric aggregation that computes the weighted centroid from all coordinate values for geo fields.
properties.name: geo_centroid

properties.description:
A multi-bucket aggregation that works on `geo_point` fields.
Evaluates the distance of each document value from an origin point and determines the buckets it belongs to, based on ranges defined in the request.
properties.name: geo_distance

properties.description:
A multi-bucket aggregation that groups `geo_point` and `geo_shape` values into buckets that represent a grid.
Each cell is labeled using a geohash which is of user-definable precision.
properties.name: geohash_grid

properties.description: Aggregates all `geo_point` values within a bucket into a `LineString` ordered by the chosen sort field.
properties.name: geo_line

properties.description:
A multi-bucket aggregation that groups `geo_point` and `geo_shape` values into buckets that represent a grid.
Each cell corresponds to a map tile as used by many online map sites.
properties.name: geotile_grid

properties.description:
A multi-bucket aggregation that groups `geo_point` and `geo_shape` values into buckets that represent a grid.
Each cell corresponds to a H3 cell index and is labeled using the H3Index representation.
properties.name: geohex_grid

properties.description:
Defines a single bucket of all the documents within the search execution context.
This context is defined by the indices and the document types you’re searching on, but is not influenced by the search query itself.
properties.name: global

properties.description:
A multi-bucket values source based aggregation that can be applied on numeric values or numeric range values extracted from the documents.
It dynamically builds fixed size (interval) buckets over the values.
properties.name: histogram

properties.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation that enables the user to define a set of IP ranges - each representing a bucket.
properties.name: ip_range

properties.description: A bucket aggregation that groups documents based on the network or sub-network of an IP address.
properties.name: ip_prefix

properties.description: A parent pipeline aggregation which loads a pre-trained model and performs inference on the collated result fields from the parent bucket aggregation.
properties.name: inference

properties.description: A numeric aggregation that computes the following statistics over a set of document fields: `count`, `mean`, `variance`, `skewness`, `kurtosis`, `covariance`, and `covariance`.
properties.name: matrix_stats

properties.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that returns the maximum value among the numeric values extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: max

properties.description: A sibling pipeline aggregation which identifies the bucket(s) with the maximum value of a specified metric in a sibling aggregation and outputs both the value and the key(s) of the bucket(s).
properties.name: max_bucket

properties.description: A single-value aggregation that approximates the median absolute deviation of its search results.
properties.name: median_absolute_deviation

properties.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that returns the minimum value among numeric values extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: min

properties.description: A sibling pipeline aggregation which identifies the bucket(s) with the minimum value of a specified metric in a sibling aggregation and outputs both the value and the key(s) of the bucket(s).
properties.name: min_bucket

properties.description: A field data based single bucket aggregation, that creates a bucket of all documents in the current document set context that are missing a field value (effectively, missing a field or having the configured NULL value set).
properties.name: missing

properties.description: Given an ordered series of percentiles, "slides" a window across those percentiles and computes cumulative percentiles.
properties.name: moving_percentiles

properties.description:
Given an ordered series of data, "slides" a window across the data and runs a custom script on each window of data.
For convenience, a number of common functions are predefined such as `min`, `max`, and moving averages.
properties.name: moving_fn

properties.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation where buckets are dynamically built - one per unique set of values.
properties.name: multi_terms

properties.description: A special single bucket aggregation that enables aggregating nested documents.
properties.name: nested

properties.description: A parent pipeline aggregation which calculates the specific normalized/rescaled value for a specific bucket value.
properties.name: normalize

properties.description: A special single bucket aggregation that selects parent documents that have the specified type, as defined in a `join` field.
properties.name: parent

properties.description: A multi-value metrics aggregation that calculates one or more percentile ranks over numeric values extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: percentile_ranks

properties.description: A multi-value metrics aggregation that calculates one or more percentiles over numeric values extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: percentiles

properties.description: A sibling pipeline aggregation which calculates percentiles across all bucket of a specified metric in a sibling aggregation.
properties.name: percentiles_bucket

properties.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation that enables the user to define a set of ranges - each representing a bucket.
properties.name: range

properties.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation which finds "rare" terms — terms that are at the long-tail of the distribution and are not frequent.
properties.name: rare_terms

properties.description:
Calculates a rate of documents or a field in each bucket.
Can only be used inside a `date_histogram` or `composite` aggregation.
properties.name: rate

properties.description:
A special single bucket aggregation that enables aggregating on parent documents from nested documents.
Should only be defined inside a `nested` aggregation.
properties.name: reverse_nested

properties.description: A filtering aggregation used to limit any sub aggregations' processing to a sample of the top-scoring documents.
properties.name: sampler

properties.description: A metric aggregation that uses scripts to provide a metric output.
properties.name: scripted_metric

properties.description: An aggregation that subtracts values in a time series from themselves at different time lags or periods.
properties.name: serial_diff

properties.description: Returns interesting or unusual occurrences of terms in a set.
properties.name: significant_terms

properties.description: Returns interesting or unusual occurrences of free-text terms in a set.
properties.name: significant_text

properties.description: A multi-value metrics aggregation that computes stats over numeric values extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: stats

properties.description: A sibling pipeline aggregation which calculates a variety of stats across all bucket of a specified metric in a sibling aggregation.
properties.name: stats_bucket

properties.description: A multi-value metrics aggregation that computes statistics over string values extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: string_stats

properties.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that sums numeric values that are extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: sum

properties.description: A sibling pipeline aggregation which calculates the sum of a specified metric across all buckets in a sibling aggregation.
properties.name: sum_bucket

properties.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation where buckets are dynamically built - one per unique value.
properties.name: terms

properties.description:
The time series aggregation queries data created using a time series index.
This is typically data such as metrics or other data streams with a time component, and requires creating an index using the time series mode.
properties.name: time_series

properties.description: A metric aggregation that returns the top matching documents per bucket.
properties.name: top_hits

properties.description: A metrics aggregation that performs a statistical hypothesis test in which the test statistic follows a Student’s t-distribution under the null hypothesis on numeric values extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: t_test

properties.description: A metric aggregation that selects metrics from the document with the largest or smallest sort value.
properties.name: top_metrics

properties.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that counts the number of values that are extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: value_count

properties.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that computes the weighted average of numeric values that are extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: weighted_avg

properties.description: A multi-bucket aggregation similar to the histogram, except instead of providing an interval to use as the width of each bucket, a target number of buckets is provided.
properties.name: variable_width_histogram

properties.description:
Filters used to create buckets.
At least one filter is required.
properties.name: filters

properties.description: Separator used to concatenate filter names. Defaults to &.
properties.name: separator

types.description: Base type for bucket aggregations. These aggregations also accept sub-aggregations.

properties.description: matches documents matching boolean combinations of other queries.
properties.name: bool

properties.description: Returns documents matching a `positive` query while reducing the relevance score of documents that also match a `negative` query.
properties.name: boosting

properties.description: The `combined_fields` query supports searching multiple text fields as if their contents had been indexed into one combined field.
properties.name: combined_fields

properties.description: Wraps a filter query and returns every matching document with a relevance score equal to the `boost` parameter value.
properties.name: constant_score

properties.description:
Returns documents matching one or more wrapped queries, called query clauses or clauses.
If a returned document matches multiple query clauses, the `dis_max` query assigns the document the highest relevance score from any matching clause, plus a tie breaking increment for any additional matching subqueries.
properties.name: dis_max

properties.description:
Boosts the relevance score of documents closer to a provided origin date or point.
For example, you can use this query to give more weight to documents closer to a certain date or location.
properties.name: distance_feature

properties.description: Returns documents that contain an indexed value for a field.
properties.name: exists

properties.description: The `function_score` enables you to modify the score of documents that are retrieved by a query.
properties.name: function_score

properties.description: Returns documents that contain terms similar to the search term, as measured by a Levenshtein edit distance.
properties.name: fuzzy

properties.description: Matches geo_point and geo_shape values that intersect a bounding box.
properties.name: geo_bounding_box

properties.description: Matches `geo_point` and `geo_shape` values within a given distance of a geopoint.
properties.name: geo_distance

properties.description: Filter documents indexed using either the `geo_shape` or the `geo_point` type.
properties.name: geo_shape

properties.description: Returns parent documents whose joined child documents match a provided query.
properties.name: has_child

properties.description: Returns child documents whose joined parent document matches a provided query.
properties.name: has_parent

properties.description:
Returns documents based on their IDs.
This query uses document IDs stored in the `_id` field.
properties.name: ids

properties.description: Returns documents based on the order and proximity of matching terms.
properties.name: intervals

properties.description:
Finds the k nearest vectors to a query vector, as measured by a similarity
metric. knn query finds nearest vectors through approximate search on indexed
dense_vectors.
properties.name: knn

properties.description:
Returns documents that match a provided text, number, date or boolean value.
The provided text is analyzed before matching.
properties.name: match

properties.description: Matches all documents, giving them all a `_score` of 1.0.
properties.name: match_all

properties.description:
Analyzes its input and constructs a `bool` query from the terms.
Each term except the last is used in a `term` query.
The last term is used in a prefix query.
properties.name: match_bool_prefix

properties.description: Matches no documents.
properties.name: match_none

properties.description: Analyzes the text and creates a phrase query out of the analyzed text.
properties.name: match_phrase

properties.description:
Returns documents that contain the words of a provided text, in the same order as provided.
The last term of the provided text is treated as a prefix, matching any words that begin with that term.
properties.name: match_phrase_prefix

properties.description: Returns documents that are "like" a given set of documents.
properties.name: more_like_this

properties.description:
Enables you to search for a provided text, number, date or boolean value across multiple fields.
The provided text is analyzed before matching.
properties.name: multi_match

properties.description:
Wraps another query to search nested fields.
If an object matches the search, the nested query returns the root parent document.
properties.name: nested

properties.description: Returns child documents joined to a specific parent document.
properties.name: parent_id

properties.description: Matches queries stored in an index.
properties.name: percolate

properties.description: Promotes selected documents to rank higher than those matching a given query.
properties.name: pinned

properties.description: Returns documents that contain a specific prefix in a provided field.
properties.name: prefix

properties.description: Returns documents based on a provided query string, using a parser with a strict syntax.
properties.name: query_string

properties.description: Returns documents that contain terms within a provided range.
properties.name: range

properties.description: Boosts the relevance score of documents based on the numeric value of a `rank_feature` or `rank_features` field.
properties.name: rank_feature

properties.description: Returns documents that contain terms matching a regular expression.
properties.name: regexp

properties.description:
Filters documents based on a provided script.
The script query is typically used in a filter context.
properties.name: script

properties.description: Uses a script to provide a custom score for returned documents.
properties.name: script_score

properties.description: A semantic query to semantic_text field types
properties.name: semantic

properties.description: Queries documents that contain fields indexed using the `shape` type.
properties.name: shape

properties.description: Returns documents based on a provided query string, using a parser with a limited but fault-tolerant syntax.
properties.name: simple_query_string

properties.description: Returns matches which enclose another span query.
properties.name: span_containing

properties.description: Wrapper to allow span queries to participate in composite single-field span queries by _lying_ about their search field.
properties.name: span_field_masking

properties.description: Matches spans near the beginning of a field.
properties.name: span_first

properties.description: Allows you to wrap a multi term query (one of `wildcard`, `fuzzy`, `prefix`, `range`, or `regexp` query) as a `span` query, so it can be nested.
properties.name: span_multi

properties.description:
Matches spans which are near one another.
You can specify `slop`, the maximum number of intervening unmatched positions, as well as whether matches are required to be in-order.
properties.name: span_near

properties.description: Removes matches which overlap with another span query or which are within x tokens before (controlled by the parameter `pre`) or y tokens after (controlled by the parameter `post`) another span query.
properties.name: span_not

properties.description: Matches the union of its span clauses.
properties.name: span_or

properties.description: Matches spans containing a term.
properties.name: span_term

properties.description: Returns matches which are enclosed inside another span query.
properties.name: span_within

properties.description: Using input query vectors or a natural language processing model to convert a query into a list of token-weight pairs, queries against a sparse vector field.
properties.name: sparse_vector

properties.description:
Returns documents that contain an exact term in a provided field.
To return a document, the query term must exactly match the queried field's value, including whitespace and capitalization.
properties.name: term

properties.description:
Returns documents that contain one or more exact terms in a provided field.
To return a document, one or more terms must exactly match a field value, including whitespace and capitalization.
properties.name: terms

properties.description:
Returns documents that contain a minimum number of exact terms in a provided field.
To return a document, a required number of terms must exactly match the field values, including whitespace and capitalization.
properties.name: terms_set

properties.description: Uses a natural language processing model to convert the query text into a list of token-weight pairs which are then used in a query against a sparse vector or rank features field.
properties.name: text_expansion

properties.description: Supports returning text_expansion query results by sending in precomputed tokens with the query.
properties.name: weighted_tokens

properties.description: Returns documents that contain terms matching a wildcard pattern.
properties.name: wildcard

properties.description: A query that accepts any other query as base64 encoded string.
properties.name: wrapper

properties.description:
The clause (query) must appear in matching documents.
However, unlike `must`, the score of the query will be ignored.
properties.name: filter

properties.description: Specifies the number or percentage of `should` clauses returned documents must match.
properties.name: minimum_should_match

properties.description: The clause (query) must appear in matching documents and will contribute to the score.
properties.name: must

properties.description:
The clause (query) must not appear in the matching documents.
Because scoring is ignored, a score of `0` is returned for all documents.
properties.name: must_not

properties.description: The clause (query) should appear in the matching document.
properties.name: should

properties.description:
Floating point number used to decrease or increase the relevance scores of the query.
Boost values are relative to the default value of 1.0.
A boost value between 0 and 1.0 decreases the relevance score.
A value greater than 1.0 increases the relevance score.
properties.name: boost

types.description: The minimum number of terms that should match as integer, percentage or range

properties.description: Floating point number between 0 and 1.0 used to decrease the relevance scores of documents matching the `negative` query.
properties.name: negative_boost

properties.description: Query used to decrease the relevance score of matching documents.
properties.name: negative

properties.description: Any returned documents must match this query.
properties.name: positive

types.description: Path to field or array of paths. Some API's support wildcards in the path to select multiple fields.

properties.description: List of fields to search. Field wildcard patterns are allowed. Only `text` fields are supported, and they must all have the same search `analyzer`.
properties.name: fields

properties.description:
Text to search for in the provided `fields`.
The `combined_fields` query analyzes the provided text before performing a search.
properties.name: query

Filter query you wish to run. Any returned documents must match this query.

properties.description:
Date or point of origin used to calculate distances.
If the `field` value is a `date` or `date_nanos` field, the `origin` value must be a date.
Date Math, such as `now-1h`, is supported.
If the field value is a `geo_point` field, the `origin` value must be a geopoint.
properties.name: origin

properties.description:
Distance from the `origin` at which relevance scores receive half of the `boost` value.
If the `field` value is a `date` or `date_nanos` field, the `pivot` value must be a time unit, such as `1h` or `10d`. If the `field` value is a `geo_point` field, the `pivot` value must be a distance unit, such as `1km` or `12m`.

types.esQuirk:
this container is valid without a variant. Despite being documented as a function, 'weight'
is actually a container property that can be combined with a function. Comment in the ES code
(SearchModule#registerScoreFunctions) says: Weight doesn't have its own parser, so every function
supports it out of the box. Can be a single function too when not associated to any other function,
which is why it needs to be registered manually here.

properties.description: Function that scores a document with a exponential decay, depending on the distance of a numeric field value of the document from an origin.

properties.description: Function that scores a document with a normal decay, depending on the distance of a numeric field value of the document from an origin.
properties.name: gauss

properties.description: Function that scores a document with a linear decay, depending on the distance of a numeric field value of the document from an origin.
properties.name: linear

properties.description:
Function allows you to use a field from a document to influence the score.
It’s similar to using the script_score function, however, it avoids the overhead of scripting.
properties.name: field_value_factor

properties.description:
Generates scores that are uniformly distributed from 0 up to but not including 1.
In case you want scores to be reproducible, it is possible to provide a `seed` and `field`.
properties.name: random_score

properties.description: Enables you to wrap another query and customize the scoring of it optionally with a computation derived from other numeric field values in the doc using a script expression.
properties.name: script_score

properties.description: Determines how the distance is calculated when a field used for computing the decay contains multiple values.
properties.name: multi_value_mode

types.description:
In some places in the specification an object consists of a static set of properties and a single additional property
with an arbitrary name but a statically defined type. This is typically used for configurations associated
to a single field. Meaning that object should theoretically extend SingleKeyDictionary but expose
a set of known keys. And possibly the object might already be part of an object graph and have a parent class.
This puts it into a bind that needs a client specific solution.
We therefore document the requirement to accept a single unknown property with this interface.

types.description:
A geo bounding box. It can be represented in various ways:
- as 4 top/bottom/left/right coordinates
- as 2 top_left / bottom_right points
- as 2 top_right / bottom_left points
- as a WKT bounding box

A latitude/longitude as a 2 dimensional point. It can be represented in various ways:
- as a `{lat, long}` object
- as a geo hash value
- as a `[lon, lat]` array
- as a string in `"<lat>, <lon>"` or WKT point formats

Specifies how to break the highlighted fragments: chars, sentence, or word.
Only valid for the unified and fvh highlighters.
Defaults to `sentence` for the `unified` highlighter. Defaults to `chars` for the `fvh` highlighter.
properties.name: boundary_scanner

Controls which locale is used to search for sentence and word boundaries.
This parameter takes a form of a language tag, for example: `"en-US"`, `"fr-FR"`, `"ja-JP"`.
properties.name: boundary_scanner_locale

properties.name: fragmenter

properties.description: The size of the highlighted fragment in characters.
properties.name: fragment_size

properties.description:
Highlight matches for a query other than the search query.
This is especially useful if you use a rescore query because those are not taken into account by highlighting by default.
properties.name: highlight_query

properties.description:
If set to a non-negative value, highlighting stops at this defined maximum limit.
The rest of the text is not processed, thus not highlighted and no error is returned
The `max_analyzed_offset` query setting does not override the `index.highlight.max_analyzed_offset` setting, which prevails when it’s set to lower value than the query setting.
properties.name: max_analyzed_offset

properties.description: The amount of text you want to return from the beginning of the field if there are no matching fragments to highlight.
properties.name: no_match_size

properties.description:
The maximum number of fragments to return.
If the number of fragments is set to `0`, no fragments are returned.
Instead, the entire field contents are highlighted and returned.
This can be handy when you need to highlight short texts such as a title or address, but fragmentation is not required.
If `number_of_fragments` is `0`, `fragment_size` is ignored.
properties.name: number_of_fragments

properties.description:
Sorts highlighted fragments by score when set to `score`.
By default, fragments will be output in the order they appear in the field (order: `none`).
Setting this option to `score` will output the most relevant fragments first.
Each highlighter applies its own logic to compute relevancy scores.
properties.name: order

properties.description:
Controls the number of matching phrases in a document that are considered.
Prevents the `fvh` highlighter from analyzing too many phrases and consuming too much memory.
When using `matched_fields`, `phrase_limit` phrases per matched field are considered. Raising the limit increases query time and consumes more memory.
Only supported by the `fvh` highlighter.
properties.name: phrase_limit

properties.description: Use in conjunction with `pre_tags` to define the HTML tags to use for the highlighted text. By default, highlighted text is wrapped in `` and `` tags.
properties.name: post_tags

properties.description: Use in conjunction with `post_tags` to define the HTML tags to use for the highlighted text. By default, highlighted text is wrapped in `` and `` tags.
properties.name: pre_tags

properties.description:
By default, only fields that contains a query match are highlighted.
Set to `false` to highlight all fields.
properties.name: require_field_match

properties.name: tags_schema

Use the characters specified by `boundary_chars` as highlighting boundaries.
The `boundary_max_scan` setting controls how far to scan for boundary characters.
Only valid for the `fvh` highlighter.

members.description:
Break highlighted fragments at the next sentence boundary, as determined by Java’s `BreakIterator`.
You can specify the locale to use with `boundary_scanner_locale`.
When used with the `unified` highlighter, the `sentence` scanner splits sentences bigger than `fragment_size` at the first word boundary next to fragment_size.
You can set `fragment_size` to `0` to never split any sentence.
members.name: sentence

members.description:
Break highlighted fragments at the next word boundary, as determined by Java’s `BreakIterator`.
You can specify the locale to use with `boundary_scanner_locale`.
members.name: word

types.description:
A sibling pipeline aggregation which executes a two sample Kolmogorov–Smirnov test (referred
to as a "K-S test" from now on) against a provided distribution, and the distribution implied
by the documents counts in the configured sibling aggregation. Specifically, for some metric,
assuming that the percentile intervals of the metric are known beforehand or have been computed
by an aggregation, then one would use range aggregation for the sibling to compute the p-value
of the distribution difference between the metric and the restriction of that metric to a subset
of the documents. A natural use case is if the sibling aggregation range aggregation nested in a
terms aggregation, in which case one compares the overall distribution of metric to its restriction
to each term.

properties.description:
A list of string values indicating which K-S test alternative to calculate. The valid values
are: "greater", "less", "two_sided". This parameter is key for determining the K-S statistic used
when calculating the K-S test. Default value is all possible alternative hypotheses.
properties.name: alternative

properties.description:
A list of doubles indicating the distribution of the samples with which to compare to the `buckets_path` results.
In typical usage this is the overall proportion of documents in each bucket, which is compared with the actual
document proportions in each bucket from the sibling aggregation counts. The default is to assume that overall
documents are uniformly distributed on these buckets, which they would be if one used equal percentiles of a
metric to define the bucket end points.
properties.name: fractions

properties.description:
Indicates the sampling methodology when calculating the K-S test. Note, this is sampling of the returned values.
This determines the cumulative distribution function (CDF) points used comparing the two samples. Default is
`upper_tail`, which emphasizes the upper end of the CDF points. Valid options are: `upper_tail`, `uniform`,
and `lower_tail`.
properties.name: sampling_method

types.description: A sibling pipeline aggregation which executes a correlation function on the configured sibling multi-bucket aggregation.

properties.description: The correlation function to execute.
properties.name: function

properties.description: The configuration to calculate a count correlation. This function is designed for determining the correlation of a term value and a given metric.
properties.name: count_correlation

properties.description: The indicator with which to correlate the configured `bucket_path` values.
properties.name: indicator

properties.description:
The total number of documents that initially created the expectations. It’s required to be greater
than or equal to the sum of all values in the buckets_path as this is the originating superset of data
to which the term values are correlated.

types.description:
A multi-bucket aggregation that groups semi-structured text into buckets. Each text
field is re-analyzed using a custom analyzer. The resulting tokens are then categorized
creating buckets of similarly formatted text values. This aggregation works best with machine
generated text like system logs. Only the first 100 analyzed tokens are used to categorize the text.

properties.description: The semi-structured text field to categorize.
properties.name: field

properties.description:
The maximum number of unique tokens at any position up to max_matched_tokens. Must be larger than 1.
Smaller values use less memory and create fewer categories. Larger values will use more memory and
create narrower categories. Max allowed value is 100.
properties.name: max_unique_tokens

properties.description:
The maximum number of token positions to match on before attempting to merge categories. Larger
values will use more memory and create narrower categories. Max allowed value is 100.
properties.name: max_matched_tokens

properties.description:
The minimum percentage of tokens that must match for text to be added to the category bucket. Must
be between 1 and 100. The larger the value the narrower the categories. Larger values will increase memory
usage and create narrower categories.
properties.name: similarity_threshold

properties.description:
This property expects an array of regular expressions. The expressions are used to filter out matching
sequences from the categorization field values. You can use this functionality to fine tune the categorization
by excluding sequences from consideration when categories are defined. For example, you can exclude SQL
statements that appear in your log files. This property cannot be used at the same time as categorization_analyzer.
If you only want to define simple regular expression filters that are applied prior to tokenization, setting
this property is the easiest method. If you also want to customize the tokenizer or post-tokenization filtering,
use the categorization_analyzer property instead and include the filters as pattern_replace character filters.
properties.name: categorization_filters

properties.description:
The categorization analyzer specifies how the text is analyzed and tokenized before being categorized.
The syntax is very similar to that used to define the analyzer in the [Analyze endpoint](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/8.0/indices-analyze.html). This property
cannot be used at the same time as categorization_filters.
properties.name: categorization_analyzer

types.description:
Defines how to fetch a source. Fetching can be disabled entirely, or the source can be filtered.
Used as a query parameter along with the `_source_includes` and `_source_excludes` parameters.

A `null` value that is to be interpreted as an actual value, unless other uses of `null` that are equivalent
to a missing value. It is used for exemple in settings, where using the `NullValue` for a setting will reset
it to its default value.

Some APIs will return values such as numbers also as a string (notably epoch timestamps). This behavior
is used to capture this behavior while keeping the semantics of the field type.

Depending on the target language, code generators can keep the union or remove it and leniently parse
strings to the target type.

The absence of any type. This is commonly used in APIs that don't return a body.

Although "void" is generally used for the unit type that has only one value, this is to be interpreted as
the bottom type that has no value at all. Most languages have a unit type, but few have a bottom type.

See https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unit_type and https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bottom_type

`WithNullValue<T>` allows for explicit null assignments in contexts where `null` should be interpreted as an
actual value.

members.description:
Computes the cosine similarity. During indexing Elasticsearch automatically normalizes vectors with `cosine`
similarity to unit length. This allows to internally use `dot_product` for computing similarity, which is more
efficient. Original un-normalized vectors can be still accessed through scripts.

The document `_score` is computed as `(1 + cosine(query, vector)) / 2`.

The `cosine` similarity does not allow vectors with zero magnitude, since cosine is not defined in this case.
members.name: cosine

members.description:
Computes the dot product of two unit vectors. This option provides an optimized way to perform cosine similarity.
The constraints and computed score are defined by `element_type`.

When `element_type` is `float`, all vectors must be unit length, including both document and query vectors.

The document `_score` is computed as `(1 + dot_product(query, vector)) / 2`.

When `element_type` is `byte`, all vectors must have the same length including both document and query vectors or
results will be inaccurate.

The document `_score` is computed as `0.5 + (dot_product(query, vector) / (32768 * dims))` where `dims` is the
number of dimensions per vector.
members.name: dot_product

members.description:
Computes similarity based on the `L2` distance (also known as Euclidean distance) between the vectors.

The document `_score` is computed as `1 / (1 + l2_norm(query, vector)^2)`.

For `bit` vectors, instead of using `l2_norm`, the `hamming` distance between the vectors is used.

The `_score` transformation is `(numBits - hamming(a, b)) / numBits`.
members.name: l2_norm

members.description:
Computes the maximum inner product of two vectors. This is similar to `dot_product`, but doesn't require vectors
to be normalized. This means that each vector’s magnitude can significantly effect the score.

The document `_score` is adjusted to prevent negative values. For `max_inner_product` values `< 0`, the `_score`
is `1 / (1 + -1 * max_inner_product(query, vector))`. For non-negative `max_inner_product` results the `_score`
is calculated `max_inner_product(query, vector) + 1`.
members.name: max_inner_product

types.esQuirk:
This is a boolean that evolved into an enum. Boolean values should be accepted on reading, and
true and false must be serialized as JSON booleans, or it may break Kibana (see elasticsearch-java#139)

properties.description: Metadata about the field.
properties.name: meta

properties.description: For internal use by Elastic only. Marks the field as a time series dimension. Defaults to false.
properties.name: time_series_dimension

types.description:
A variant of text that trades scoring and efficiency of positional queries for space efficiency. This field
effectively stores data the same way as a text field that only indexes documents (index_options: docs) and
disables norms (norms: false). Term queries perform as fast if not faster as on text fields, however queries
that need positions such as the match_phrase query perform slower as they need to look at the _source document
to verify whether a phrase matches. All queries return constant scores that are equal to 1.0.

properties.description:
Multi-fields allow the same string value to be indexed in multiple ways for different purposes, such as one
field for search and a multi-field for sorting and aggregations, or the same string value analyzed by different analyzers.
properties.name: fields

properties.description: Metadata about the field.
properties.name: meta

properties.description:
Allows you to copy the values of multiple fields into a group
field, which can then be queried as a single field.
properties.name: copy_to

properties.description:
Number of vector dimensions. Can't exceed `4096`. If `dims` is not specified, it will be set to the length of
the first vector added to the field.
properties.name: dims

properties.description: The data type used to encode vectors. The supported data types are `float` (default), `byte`, and `bit`.
properties.name: element_type

properties.description: If `true`, you can search this field using the kNN search API.
properties.name: index

properties.description:
An optional section that configures the kNN indexing algorithm. The HNSW algorithm has two internal parameters
that influence how the data structure is built. These can be adjusted to improve the accuracy of results, at the
expense of slower indexing speed.

This parameter can only be specified when `index` is `true`.
properties.name: index_options

properties.description:
The vector similarity metric to use in kNN search.

Documents are ranked by their vector field's similarity to the query vector. The `_score` of each document will
be derived from the similarity, in a way that ensures scores are positive and that a larger score corresponds
to a higher ranking.

Defaults to `l2_norm` when `element_type` is `bit` otherwise defaults to `cosine`.

`bit` vectors only support `l2_norm` as their similarity metric.

This parameter can only be specified when `index` is `true`.
properties.name: similarity

properties.description:
The confidence interval to use when quantizing the vectors. Can be any value between and including `0.90` and
`1.0` or exactly `0`. When the value is `0`, this indicates that dynamic quantiles should be calculated for
optimized quantization. When between `0.90` and `1.0`, this value restricts the values used when calculating
the quantization thresholds.

For example, a value of `0.95` will only use the middle `95%` of the values when calculating the quantization
thresholds (e.g. the highest and lowest `2.5%` of values will be ignored).

Defaults to `1/(dims + 1)` for `int8` quantized vectors and `0` for `int4` for dynamic quantile calculation.

Only applicable to `int8_hnsw`, `int4_hnsw`, `int8_flat`, and `int4_flat` index types.
properties.name: confidence_interval

properties.description:
The number of candidates to track while assembling the list of nearest neighbors for each new node.

Only applicable to `hnsw`, `int8_hnsw`, and `int4_hnsw` index types.
properties.name: ef_construction

properties.description:
The number of neighbors each node will be connected to in the HNSW graph.

Only applicable to `hnsw`, `int8_hnsw`, and `int4_hnsw` index types.
properties.name: m

properties.description: The type of kNN algorithm to use.
properties.name: type

properties.description: For internal use by Elastic only. Marks the field as a time series dimension. Defaults to false.
properties.name: time_series_dimension

types.description:
The `geo_shape` data type facilitates the indexing of and searching with arbitrary geo shapes such as rectangles
and polygons.

The `shape` data type facilitates the indexing of and searching with arbitrary `x, y` cartesian shapes such as
rectangles and polygons.

properties.description: For internal use by Elastic only. Marks the field as a time series dimension. Defaults to false.

properties.description: For internal use by Elastic only. Marks the field as a time series dimension. Defaults to false.

members.description:
The status of categorization for the job: `ok` or `warn`. If `ok`,
categorization is performing acceptably well (or not being used at all). If
`warn`, categorization is detecting a distribution of categories that
suggests the input data is inappropriate for categorization. Problems could
be that there is only one category, more than 90% of categories are rare,
the number of categories is greater than 50% of the number of categorized
documents, there are no frequently matched categories, or more than 50% of
categories are dead.
members.name: model.categorization_status

members.description: The number of documents that have had a field categorized.

members.description:
The number of categories created by categorization that will never be

the dead category. Dead categories are a side effect of the way
categorization has no prior training.
members.name: model.dead_category_count

members.description:
The number of times that categorization wanted to create a new category but
couldn’t because the job had hit its model memory limit. This count does
not track which specific categories failed to be created. Therefore, you
cannot use this value to determine the number of unique categories that
were missed.
members.name: model.failed_category_count

members.description: The number of categories that match more than 1% of categorized documents.
members.name: model.frequent_category_count

members.description:
The status of the mathematical models: `ok`, `soft_limit`, or `hard_limit`.
If `ok`, the models stayed below the configured value. If `soft_limit`, the
models used more than 60% of the configured memory limit and older unused
models will be pruned to free up space. Additionally, in categorization jobs
no further category examples will be stored. If `hard_limit`, the models
used more space than the configured memory limit. As a result, not all
incoming data was processed.
members.name: model.memory_status

members.description:
The status of the anomaly detection job: `closed`, `closing`, `failed`,
`opened`, or `opening`. If `closed`, the job finished successfully with its
model state persisted. The job must be opened before it can accept further
data. If `closing`, the job close action is in progress and has not yet
completed. A closing job cannot accept further data. If `failed`, the job
did not finish successfully due to an error. This situation can occur due
to invalid input data, a fatal error occurring during the analysis, or an
external interaction such as the process being killed by the Linux out of
memory (OOM) killer. If the job had irrevocably failed, it must be force
closed and then deleted. If the datafeed can be corrected, the job can be
closed and then re-opened. If `opened`, the job is available to receive and
process data. If `opening`, the job open action is in progress and has not
yet completed.

members.description:
Default file system implementation. This will pick the best implementation depending on the operating environment, which
is currently hybridfs on all supported systems but is subject to change.
members.name: fs

members.description:
The NIO FS type stores the shard index on the file system (maps to Lucene NIOFSDirectory) using NIO. It allows multiple
threads to read from the same file concurrently. It is not recommended on Windows because of a bug in the SUN Java
implementation and disables some optimizations for heap memory usage.
members.name: niofs

members.description:
The MMap FS type stores the shard index on the file system (maps to Lucene MMapDirectory) by mapping a file into
memory (mmap). Memory mapping uses up a portion of the virtual memory address space in your process equal to the size
of the file being mapped. Before using this class, be sure you have allowed plenty of virtual address space.
members.name: mmapfs

members.description:
The hybridfs type is a hybrid of niofs and mmapfs, which chooses the best file system type for each type of file
based on the read access pattern. Currently only the Lucene term dictionary, norms and doc values files are memory
mapped. All other files are opened using Lucene NIOFSDirectory. Similarly to mmapfs be sure you have allowed
plenty of virtual address space.
members.name: hybridfs

members.description:
(default) fsync and commit after every request. In the event of hardware failure, all acknowledged writes
will already have been committed to disk.
members.name: request

members.description:
fsync and commit in the background every sync_interval. In the event of a failure, all acknowledged writes
since the last automatic commit will be discarded.
members.name: async

members.description: The primary shard and all replica shards are assigned.
members.name: green

members.description: One or more replica shards are unassigned.
members.name: yellow

members.description: The primary shard is unassigned.
members.name: red

members.description: Return all shards, regardless of health status.
members.name: all

types.description:
Text Embedding results containing bytes are represented as Dense
Vectors of bytes.

Text Embedding results are represented as Dense Vectors
of floats.

Sparse Embedding tokens are represented as a dictionary
of string to double.

properties.description: One or more character filters. In addition to the built-in character filters, other plugins can provide more character filters. If this property is not specified, no character filters are applied prior to categorization. If you are customizing some other aspect of the analyzer and you need to achieve the equivalent of `categorization_filters` (which are not permitted when some other aspect of the analyzer is customized), add them here as pattern replace character filters.
properties.name: char_filter

properties.description: One or more token filters. In addition to the built-in token filters, other plugins can provide more token filters. If this property is not specified, no token filters are applied prior to categorization.
properties.name: filter

properties.description: The name or definition of the tokenizer to use after character filters are applied. This property is compulsory if `categorization_analyzer` is specified as an object. Machine learning provides a tokenizer called `ml_standard` that tokenizes in a way that has been determined to produce good categorization results on a variety of log file formats for logs in English. If you want to use that tokenizer but change the character or token filters, specify "tokenizer": "ml_standard" in your `categorization_analyzer`. Additionally, the `ml_classic` tokenizer is available, which tokenizes in the same way as the non-customizable tokenizer in old versions of the product (before 6.2). `ml_classic` was the default categorization tokenizer in versions 6.2 to 7.13, so if you need categorization identical to the default for jobs created in these versions, specify "tokenizer": "ml_classic" in your `categorization_analyzer`.
properties.name: tokenizer

members.description: Includes the baseline for feature importance values.
members.name: feature_importance_baseline

members.description:
Includes the information about hyperparameters used to train the model.
This information consists of the value, the absolute and relative
importance of the hyperparameter as well as an indicator of whether it was
specified by the user or tuned during hyperparameter optimization.
members.name: hyperparameters

members.description:
Includes the total feature importance for the training data set. The
baseline and total feature importance values are returned in the metadata
field in the response body.
members.name: total_feature_importance

members.description: Includes the model definition status.
members.name: definition_status

members.description: The job close action is in progress and has not yet completed. A closing job cannot accept further data.
members.name: closing

members.description: The job finished successfully with its model state persisted. The job must be opened before it can accept further data.
members.name: closed

members.description: The job is available to receive and process data.
members.name: opened

members.description:
The job did not finish successfully due to an error.
This situation can occur due to invalid input data, a fatal error occurring during the analysis, or an external interaction such as the process being killed by the Linux out of memory (OOM) killer.
If the job had irrevocably failed, it must be force closed and then deleted.
If the datafeed can be corrected, the job can be closed and then re-opened.
members.name: failed

members.description: The job open action is in progress and has not yet completed.
members.name: opening

members.description: The allocation attempt failed.
members.name: failed

members.description: The trained model is allocated and ready to accept inference requests.
members.name: started

members.description: The trained model is attempting to allocate on this node; inference requests are not yet accepted.
members.name: starting

members.description: The trained model is fully deallocated from this node.
members.name: stopped

members.description: The trained model is being deallocated from this node.
members.name: stopping

members.description: The result will not be created. Unless you also specify `skip_model_update`, the model will be updated as usual with the corresponding series value.
members.name: skip_result

members.description: The value for that series will not be used to update the model. Unless you also specify `skip_result`, the results will be created as usual. This action is suitable when certain values are expected to be consistently anomalous and they affect the model in a way that negatively impacts the rest of the results.
members.name: skip_model_update

members.description: The model definition is an ensemble model of decision trees.

members.description: A special type reserved for language identification models.

members.description:
The stored definition is a PyTorch (specifically a TorchScript) model.
Currently only NLP models are supported.

The maximum amount of user memory (including file cache) allowed for all tasks in the same cgroup as the Elasticsearch process.
This value can be too big to store in a `long`, so is returned as a string so that the value returned can exactly match what the underlying operating system interface returns.
Any value that is too large to parse into a `long` almost certainly means no limit has been set for the cgroup.

properties.description:
Contains low-level statistics about how long various activities took during cluster state updates while the node was the elected master.
Omitted if the node is not master-eligible.
Every field whose name ends in `_time` within this object is also represented as a raw number of milliseconds in a field whose name ends in `_time_millis`.
The human-readable fields with a `_time` suffix are only returned if requested with the `?human=true` query parameter.
properties.name: cluster_state_update

properties.description: The cumulative amount of time, in milliseconds, spent computing no-op cluster state updates since the node started.
properties.name: computation_time_millis

properties.description:
The cumulative amount of time spent publishing cluster state updates which ultimately succeeded, which includes everything from the start of the publication (just after the computation of the new cluster state) until the publication has finished and the master node is ready to start processing the next state update.
This includes the time measured by `context_construction_time`, `commit_time`, `completion_time` and `master_apply_time`.
properties.name: publication_time

properties.description:
The cumulative amount of time, in milliseconds, spent publishing cluster state updates which ultimately succeeded, which includes everything from the start of the publication (just after the computation of the new cluster state) until the publication has finished and the master node is ready to start processing the next state update.
This includes the time measured by `context_construction_time`, `commit_time`, `completion_time` and `master_apply_time`.
properties.name: publication_time_millis

properties.description:
The cumulative amount of time spent constructing a publication context since the node started for publications that ultimately succeeded.
This statistic includes the time spent computing the difference between the current and new cluster state preparing a serialized representation of this difference.
properties.name: context_construction_time

properties.description:
The cumulative amount of time, in milliseconds, spent constructing a publication context since the node started for publications that ultimately succeeded.
This statistic includes the time spent computing the difference between the current and new cluster state preparing a serialized representation of this difference.
properties.name: context_construction_time_millis

properties.description: The cumulative amount of time spent waiting for a successful cluster state update to commit, which measures the time from the start of each publication until a majority of the master-eligible nodes have written the state to disk and confirmed the write to the elected master.
properties.name: commit_time

properties.description: The cumulative amount of time, in milliseconds, spent waiting for a successful cluster state update to commit, which measures the time from the start of each publication until a majority of the master-eligible nodes have written the state to disk and confirmed the write to the elected master.
properties.name: commit_time_millis

properties.description: The cumulative amount of time spent waiting for a successful cluster state update to complete, which measures the time from the start of each publication until all the other nodes have notified the elected master that they have applied the cluster state.
properties.name: completion_time

properties.description: The cumulative amount of time, in milliseconds,  spent waiting for a successful cluster state update to complete, which measures the time from the start of each publication until all the other nodes have notified the elected master that they have applied the cluster state.
properties.name: completion_time_millis

properties.description: The cumulative amount of time spent successfully applying cluster state updates on the elected master since the node started.
properties.name: master_apply_time

properties.description: The cumulative amount of time, in milliseconds, spent successfully applying cluster state updates on the elected master since the node started.
properties.name: master_apply_time_millis

properties.description: The cumulative amount of time spent notifying listeners of a no-op cluster state update since the node started.
properties.name: notification_time

properties.description: The cumulative amount of time, in milliseconds, spent notifying listeners of a no-op cluster state update since the node started.
properties.name: notification_time_millis

properties.description: Number of published cluster states.
properties.name: full_states

types.description:
While creating or updating a role you can provide either a JSON structure or a string to the API.
However, the response provided by Elasticsearch will only be string with a json-as-text content.

Since this is embedded in `IndicesPrivileges`, the same structure is used for clarity in both contexts.

properties.description:
When you create a role, you can specify a query that defines the document level security permissions. You can optionally
use Mustache templates in the role query to insert the username of the current authenticated user into the role.
Like other places in Elasticsearch that support templating or scripting, you can specify inline, stored, or file-based
templates and define custom parameters. You access the details for the current authenticated user through the _user parameter.
properties.name: template

properties.description: The `id` for a stored script.
properties.name: id

properties.description:
Specifies any named parameters that are passed into the script as variables.
Use parameters instead of hard-coded values to decrease compile time.
properties.name: params

properties.description: Specifies the language the script is written in.
properties.name: lang

members.name: FINALIZE

members.description: Number of shards in the snapshot that are in the initializing stage of being stored in the repository.
members.name: INIT

members.description: Number of shards in the snapshot that are in the started stage of being stored in the repository.
members.name: STARTED
