properties.name: timing_stats

properties.description: Indicates that the process of deleting the job is in progress but not yet completed. It is only reported when `true`.
properties.name: deleting

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option.
Specifies whether this job can open when there is insufficient machine learning node capacity for it to be immediately assigned to a node.
properties.name: allow_lazy_open

properties.description:
The analysis configuration, which specifies how to analyze the data.
After you create a job, you cannot change the analysis configuration; all the properties are informational.
properties.name: analysis_config

properties.description:
Limits can be applied for the resources required to hold the mathematical models in memory.
These limits are approximate and can be set per job.
They do not control the memory used by other processes, for example the Elasticsearch Java processes.
properties.name: analysis_limits

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option.
The time between each periodic persistence of the model.
The default value is a randomized value between 3 to 4 hours, which avoids all jobs persisting at exactly the same time.
The smallest allowed value is 1 hour.
properties.name: background_persist_interval

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option.
Contains custom metadata about the job.
properties.name: custom_settings

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option, which affects the automatic removal of old model snapshots for this job.
It specifies a period of time (in days) after which only the first snapshot per day is retained.
This period is relative to the timestamp of the most recent snapshot for this job.
Valid values range from 0 to `model_snapshot_retention_days`.
properties.name: daily_model_snapshot_retention_after_days

properties.description:
The data description defines the format of the input data when you send data to the job by using the post data API.
Note that when configuring a datafeed, these properties are automatically set.
When data is received via the post data API, it is not stored in Elasticsearch.
Only the results for anomaly detection are retained.
properties.name: data_description

properties.description:
The datafeed, which retrieves data from Elasticsearch for analysis by the job.
You can associate only one datafeed with each anomaly detection job.
properties.name: datafeed_config

properties.description:
Indicates that the process of deleting the job is in progress but not yet completed.
It is only reported when `true`.
properties.name: deleting

properties.description: A description of the job.
properties.name: description

properties.description:
If the job closed or failed, this is the time the job finished, otherwise it is `null`.
This property is informational; you cannot change its value.
properties.name: finished_time

properties.description:
A list of job groups.
A job can belong to no groups or many.
properties.name: groups

properties.description:
Identifier for the anomaly detection job.
This identifier can contain lowercase alphanumeric characters (a-z and 0-9), hyphens, and underscores.
It must start and end with alphanumeric characters.
properties.name: job_id

properties.description: Reserved for future use, currently set to `anomaly_detector`.
properties.name: job_type

properties.description: The machine learning configuration version number at which the the job was created.
properties.name: job_version

properties.description:
This advanced configuration option stores model information along with the results.
It provides a more detailed view into anomaly detection.
Model plot provides a simplified and indicative view of the model and its bounds.
properties.name: model_plot_config

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option, which affects the automatic removal of old model snapshots for this job.
It specifies the maximum period of time (in days) that snapshots are retained.
This period is relative to the timestamp of the most recent snapshot for this job.
By default, snapshots ten days older than the newest snapshot are deleted.
properties.name: model_snapshot_retention_days

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option.
The period over which adjustments to the score are applied, as new data is seen.
The default value is the longer of 30 days or 100 `bucket_spans`.
properties.name: renormalization_window_days

properties.description:
A text string that affects the name of the machine learning results index.
The default value is `shared`, which generates an index named `.ml-anomalies-shared`.
properties.name: results_index_name

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option.
The period of time (in days) that results are retained.
Age is calculated relative to the timestamp of the latest bucket result.
If this property has a non-null value, once per day at 00:30 (server time), results that are the specified number of days older than the latest bucket result are deleted from Elasticsearch.
The default value is null, which means all results are retained.
Annotations generated by the system also count as results for retention purposes; they are deleted after the same number of days as results.
Annotations added by users are retained forever.
properties.name: results_retention_days

properties.description: The maximum number of examples stored per category in memory and in the results data store. If you increase this value, more examples are available, however it requires that you have more storage available. If you set this value to 0, no examples are stored. NOTE: The `categorization_examples_limit` applies only to analysis that uses categorization.
properties.name: categorization_examples_limit

properties.description: The approximate maximum amount of memory resources that are required for analytical processing. Once this limit is approached, data pruning becomes more aggressive. Upon exceeding this limit, new entities are not modeled. If the `xpack.ml.max_model_memory_limit` setting has a value greater than 0 and less than 1024mb, that value is used instead of the default. The default value is relatively small to ensure that high resource usage is a conscious decision. If you have jobs that are expected to analyze high cardinality fields, you will likely need to use a higher value. If you specify a number instead of a string, the units are assumed to be MiB. Specifying a string is recommended for clarity. If you specify a byte size unit of `b` or `kb` and the number does not equate to a discrete number of megabytes, it is rounded down to the closest MiB. The minimum valid value is 1 MiB. If you specify a value less than 1 MiB, an error occurs. If you specify a value for the `xpack.ml.max_model_memory_limit` setting, an error occurs when you try to create jobs that have `model_memory_limit` values greater than that setting value.
properties.name: model_memory_limit

properties.description: Only JSON format is supported at this time.
properties.name: format

properties.description: The name of the field that contains the timestamp.
properties.name: time_field

properties.description: The time format, which can be `epoch`, `epoch_ms`, or a custom pattern. The value `epoch` refers to UNIX or Epoch time (the number of seconds since 1 Jan 1970). The value `epoch_ms` indicates that time is measured in milliseconds since the epoch. The `epoch` and `epoch_ms` time formats accept either integer or real values. Custom patterns must conform to the Java DateTimeFormatter class. When you use date-time formatting patterns, it is recommended that you provide the full date, time and time zone. For example: `yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ssX`. If the pattern that you specify is not sufficient to produce a complete timestamp, job creation fails.
properties.name: time_format

properties.description: A positive number showing how much the parameter influences the variation of the loss function. For hyperparameters with values that are not specified by the user but tuned during hyperparameter optimization.
properties.name: absolute_importance

properties.description: Name of the hyperparameter.
properties.name: name

properties.description: A number between 0 and 1 showing the proportion of influence on the variation of the loss function among all tuned hyperparameters. For hyperparameters with values that are not specified by the user but tuned during hyperparameter optimization.
properties.name: relative_importance

properties.description: Indicates if the hyperparameter is specified by the user (true) or optimized (false).
properties.name: supplied

properties.description: The value of the hyperparameter, either optimized or specified by the user.
properties.name: value

properties.description: The feature for which this importance was calculated.
properties.name: feature_name

properties.description: A collection of feature importance statistics related to the training data set for this particular feature.
properties.name: importance

properties.description: If the trained model is a classification model, feature importance statistics are gathered per target class value.
properties.name: classes

properties.description: The average magnitude of this feature across all the training data. This value is the average of the absolute values of the importance for this feature.
properties.name: mean_magnitude

properties.description: The maximum importance value across all the training data for this feature.
properties.name: max

properties.description: The minimum importance value across all the training data for this feature.
properties.name: min

properties.description: The target class value. Could be a string, boolean, or number.
properties.name: class_name

properties.description: A collection of feature importance statistics related to the training data set for this particular feature.
properties.name: importance

properties.description: String prepended to input at ingest

properties.description: String prepended to input at search
properties.name: search

properties.description: A collection of deployment stats, which is present when the models are deployed.

properties.description: A collection of inference stats fields.

properties.description:
A collection of ingest stats for the model across all nodes.
The values are summations of the individual node statistics.
The format matches the ingest section in the nodes stats API.
properties.name: ingest

properties.description: The unique identifier of the trained model.
properties.name: model_id

properties.description: A collection of model size stats.

properties.description: The number of ingest pipelines that currently refer to the model.

properties.description: The detailed allocation status for the deployment.
properties.name: allocation_status

properties.description: The unique identifier for the trained model deployment.

properties.description: The sum of `error_count` for all nodes in the deployment.
properties.name: error_count

properties.description: The sum of `inference_count` for all nodes in the deployment.

properties.description: The unique identifier for the trained model.
properties.name: model_id

properties.description:
The deployment stats for each node that currently has the model allocated.
In serverless, stats are reported for a single unnamed virtual node.
properties.name: nodes

properties.description: The number of allocations requested.
properties.name: number_of_allocations

properties.description: The number of inference requests that can be queued before new requests are rejected.
properties.name: queue_capacity

properties.description:
The sum of `rejected_execution_count` for all nodes in the deployment.
Individual nodes reject an inference request if the inference queue is full.
The queue size is controlled by the `queue_capacity` setting in the start
trained model deployment API.
properties.name: rejected_execution_count

properties.description:
The reason for the current deployment state. Usually only populated when
the model is not deployed to a node.

properties.description: The epoch timestamp when the deployment started.

properties.description: The overall state of the deployment.

properties.description: The number of threads used be each allocation during inference.

properties.description: The sum of `timeout_count` for all nodes in the deployment.

properties.description: The current number of nodes where the model is allocated.

properties.description: The detailed allocation state related to the nodes.

properties.description: The desired number of nodes for model allocation.
properties.name: target_allocation_count

properties.description: The average time for each inference call to complete on this node.
properties.name: average_inference_time_ms

properties.description: The number of errors when evaluating the trained model.
properties.name: error_count

properties.description: The total number of inference calls made against this node for this model.
properties.name: inference_count

properties.description: The epoch time stamp of the last inference call for the model on this node.
properties.name: last_access

properties.description: The number of allocations assigned to this node.
properties.name: number_of_allocations

properties.description: The number of inference requests queued to be processed.
properties.name: number_of_pending_requests

properties.description: The number of inference requests that were not processed because the queue was full.
properties.name: rejection_execution_count

properties.description: The current routing state and reason for the current routing state for this allocation.
properties.name: routing_state

properties.description: The epoch timestamp when the allocation started.
properties.name: start_time

properties.description: The number of threads used by each allocation during inference.
properties.name: threads_per_allocation

properties.description: The number of inference requests that timed out before being processed.
properties.name: timeout_count

properties.description:
The reason for the current state. It is usually populated only when the
`routing_state` is `failed`.
properties.name: reason

properties.description: The current routing state.
properties.name: routing_state

properties.description: Current number of allocations.
properties.name: current_allocations

properties.description: Target number of allocations.
properties.name: target_allocations

properties.description:
The number of times the model was loaded for inference and was not retrieved from the cache.
If this number is close to the `inference_count`, the cache is not being appropriately used.
This can be solved by increasing the cache size or its time-to-live (TTL).
Refer to general machine learning settings for the appropriate settings.
properties.name: cache_miss_count

properties.description: The number of failures when using the model for inference.
properties.name: failure_count

properties.description:
The total number of times the model has been called for inference.
This is across all inference contexts, including all pipelines.
properties.name: inference_count

properties.description: The number of inference calls where all the training features for the model were missing.
properties.name: missing_all_fields_count

properties.description: The time when the statistics were last updated.
properties.name: timestamp

properties.description: The size of the model in bytes.
properties.name: model_size_bytes

properties.description: The amount of memory required to load the model in bytes.
properties.name: required_native_memory_bytes

properties.description: Regression configuration for inference.
properties.name: regression

properties.description: Update the configured multi label option. Indicates if more than one true label exists. Defaults to the configured value.
properties.name: multi_label

properties.description: The field that is added to incoming documents to contain the inference prediction. Defaults to predicted_value.
properties.name: results_field

properties.description: The question to answer given the inference context
properties.name: question

properties.description: Specifies the number of top class predictions to return. Defaults to 0.
properties.name: num_top_classes

properties.description: The tokenization options to update when inferring
properties.name: tokenization

properties.description: The field that is added to incoming documents to contain the inference prediction. Defaults to predicted_value.
properties.name: results_field

properties.description: The maximum answer length to consider for extraction
properties.name: max_answer_length

properties.description: If the model is trained for named entity recognition (NER) tasks, the response contains the recognized entities.
properties.name: entities

properties.description:
Indicates whether the input text was truncated to meet the model's maximum sequence length limit. This property
is present only when it is true.
properties.name: is_truncated

properties.description:
If the model is trained for a text classification or zero shot classification task, the response is the
predicted class.
For named entity recognition (NER) tasks, it contains the annotated text output.
For fill mask tasks, it contains the top prediction for replacing the mask token.
For text embedding tasks, it contains the raw numerical text embedding values.
For regression models, its a numerical value
For classification models, it may be an integer, double, boolean or string depending on prediction type
properties.name: predicted_value

properties.description:
For fill mask tasks, the response contains the input text sequence with the mask token replaced by the predicted
value.
Additionally
properties.name: predicted_value_sequence

properties.description: Specifies a probability for the predicted value.
properties.name: prediction_probability

properties.description: Specifies a confidence score for the predicted value.
properties.name: prediction_score

properties.description:
For fill mask, text classification, and zero shot classification tasks, the response contains a list of top
class entries.
properties.name: top_classes

properties.description: If the request failed, the response contains the reason for the failure.
properties.name: warning

properties.description: The feature importance for the inference results. Relevant only for classification or regression models
properties.name: feature_importance

properties.description: If set, the datafeed performs aggregation searches. Support for aggregations is limited and should be used only with low cardinality data.
properties.name: aggregations

properties.description: Datafeeds might be required to search over long time periods, for several months or years. This search is split into time chunks in order to ensure the load on Elasticsearch is managed. Chunking configuration controls how the size of these time chunks are calculated and is an advanced configuration option.
properties.name: chunking_config

properties.description: A numerical character string that uniquely identifies the datafeed. This identifier can contain lowercase alphanumeric characters (a-z and 0-9), hyphens, and underscores. It must start and end with alphanumeric characters. The default value is the job identifier.
properties.name: datafeed_id

properties.description: Specifies whether the datafeed checks for missing data and the size of the window. The datafeed can optionally search over indices that have already been read in an effort to determine whether any data has subsequently been added to the index. If missing data is found, it is a good indication that the `query_delay` option is set too low and the data is being indexed after the datafeed has passed that moment in time. This check runs only on real-time datafeeds.
properties.name: delayed_data_check_config

properties.description: The interval at which scheduled queries are made while the datafeed runs in real time. The default value is either the bucket span for short bucket spans, or, for longer bucket spans, a sensible fraction of the bucket span. For example: `150s`. When `frequency` is shorter than the bucket span, interim results for the last (partial) bucket are written then eventually overwritten by the full bucket results. If the datafeed uses aggregations, this value must be divisible by the interval of the date histogram aggregation.
properties.name: frequency

properties.description: An array of index names. Wildcards are supported. If any indices are in remote clusters, the machine learning nodes must have the `remote_cluster_client` role.
properties.name: indices

properties.description: Specifies index expansion options that are used during search.
properties.name: indices_options

properties.description: If a real-time datafeed has never seen any data (including during any initial training period) then it will automatically stop itself and close its associated job after this many real-time searches that return no documents. In other words, it will stop after `frequency` times `max_empty_searches` of real-time operation. If not set then a datafeed with no end time that sees no data will remain started until it is explicitly stopped.
properties.name: max_empty_searches

properties.description: The Elasticsearch query domain-specific language (DSL). This value corresponds to the query object in an Elasticsearch search POST body. All the options that are supported by Elasticsearch can be used, as this object is passed verbatim to Elasticsearch.
properties.name: query

properties.description: The number of seconds behind real time that data is queried. For example, if data from 10:04 a.m. might not be searchable in Elasticsearch until 10:06 a.m., set this property to 120 seconds. The default value is randomly selected between `60s` and `120s`. This randomness improves the query performance when there are multiple jobs running on the same node.
properties.name: query_delay

properties.description: Specifies runtime fields for the datafeed search.
properties.name: runtime_mappings

properties.description: Specifies scripts that evaluate custom expressions and returns script fields to the datafeed. The detector configuration objects in a job can contain functions that use these script fields.
properties.name: script_fields

properties.description: The size parameter that is used in Elasticsearch searches when the datafeed does not use aggregations. The maximum value is the value of `index.max_result_window`, which is 10,000 by default.
properties.name: scroll_size

properties.description: Advanced configuration option. Specifies whether this job can open when there is insufficient machine learning node capacity for it to be immediately assigned to a node.
properties.name: allow_lazy_open

properties.description:
The analysis configuration, which specifies how to analyze the data.
After you create a job, you cannot change the analysis configuration; all the properties are informational.
properties.name: analysis_config

properties.description:
Limits can be applied for the resources required to hold the mathematical models in memory.
These limits are approximate and can be set per job.
They do not control the memory used by other processes, for example the Elasticsearch Java processes.
properties.name: analysis_limits

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option.
The time between each periodic persistence of the model.
The default value is a randomized value between 3 to 4 hours, which avoids all jobs persisting at exactly the same time.
The smallest allowed value is 1 hour.
properties.name: background_persist_interval

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option.
Contains custom metadata about the job.
properties.name: custom_settings

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option, which affects the automatic removal of old model snapshots for this job.
It specifies a period of time (in days) after which only the first snapshot per day is retained.
This period is relative to the timestamp of the most recent snapshot for this job.
properties.name: daily_model_snapshot_retention_after_days

properties.description:
The data description defines the format of the input data when you send data to the job by using the post data API.
Note that when configure a datafeed, these properties are automatically set.
properties.name: data_description

properties.description:
The datafeed, which retrieves data from Elasticsearch for analysis by the job.
You can associate only one datafeed with each anomaly detection job.
properties.name: datafeed_config

properties.description: A description of the job.
properties.name: description

properties.description: A list of job groups. A job can belong to no groups or many.
properties.name: groups

properties.description:
Identifier for the anomaly detection job.
This identifier can contain lowercase alphanumeric characters (a-z and 0-9), hyphens, and underscores.
It must start and end with alphanumeric characters.
properties.name: job_id

properties.description: Reserved for future use, currently set to `anomaly_detector`.
properties.name: job_type

properties.description:
This advanced configuration option stores model information along with the results.
It provides a more detailed view into anomaly detection.
Model plot provides a simplified and indicative view of the model and its bounds.
properties.name: model_plot_config

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option, which affects the automatic removal of old model snapshots for this job.
It specifies the maximum period of time (in days) that snapshots are retained.
This period is relative to the timestamp of the most recent snapshot for this job.
The default value is `10`, which means snapshots ten days older than the newest snapshot are deleted.
properties.name: model_snapshot_retention_days

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option.
The period over which adjustments to the score are applied, as new data is seen.
The default value is the longer of 30 days or 100 `bucket_spans`.
properties.name: renormalization_window_days

properties.description:
A text string that affects the name of the machine learning results index.
The default value is `shared`, which generates an index named `.ml-anomalies-shared`.
properties.name: results_index_name

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option.
The period of time (in days) that results are retained.
Age is calculated relative to the timestamp of the latest bucket result.
If this property has a non-null value, once per day at 00:30 (server time), results that are the specified number of days older than the latest bucket result are deleted from Elasticsearch.
The default value is null, which means all results are retained.
Annotations generated by the system also count as results for retention purposes; they are deleted after the same number of days as results.
Annotations added by users are retained forever.
properties.name: results_retention_days

properties.description: The size of the interval that the analysis is aggregated into, typically between `5m` and `1h`.
properties.name: bucket_span

properties.description:
If `categorization_field_name` is specified, you can also define the analyzer that is used to interpret the categorization field.
This property cannot be used at the same time as `categorization_filters`.
The categorization analyzer specifies how the `categorization_field` is interpreted by the categorization process.
properties.name: categorization_analyzer

properties.description:
If this property is specified, the values of the specified field will be categorized.
The resulting categories must be used in a detector by setting `by_field_name`, `over_field_name`, or `partition_field_name` to the keyword `mlcategory`.
properties.name: categorization_field_name

properties.description:
If `categorization_field_name` is specified, you can also define optional filters.
This property expects an array of regular expressions.
The expressions are used to filter out matching sequences from the categorization field values.
properties.name: categorization_filters

properties.description:
An array of detector configuration objects.
Detector configuration objects specify which data fields a job analyzes.
They also specify which analytical functions are used.
You can specify multiple detectors for a job.
properties.name: detectors

properties.description:
A comma separated list of influencer field names.
Typically these can be the by, over, or partition fields that are used in the detector configuration.
You might also want to use a field name that is not specifically named in a detector, but is available as part of the input data.
When you use multiple detectors, the use of influencers is recommended as it aggregates results for each influencer entity.
properties.name: influencers

properties.description:
Advanced configuration option.
Affects the pruning of models that have not been updated for the given time duration.
The value must be set to a multiple of the `bucket_span`.
If set too low, important information may be removed from the model.
Typically, set to `30d` or longer.
If not set, model pruning only occurs if the model memory status reaches the soft limit or the hard limit.
For jobs created in 8.1 and later, the default value is the greater of `30d` or 20 times `bucket_span`.
properties.name: model_prune_window

properties.description:
The size of the window in which to expect data that is out of time order.
Defaults to no latency.
If you specify a non-zero value, it must be greater than or equal to one second.
properties.name: latency

properties.description:
This functionality is reserved for internal use.
It is not supported for use in customer environments and is not subject to the support SLA of official GA features.
If set to `true`, the analysis will automatically find correlations between metrics for a given by field value and report anomalies when those correlations cease to hold.
properties.name: multivariate_by_fields

properties.description: Settings related to how categorization interacts with partition fields.
properties.name: per_partition_categorization

properties.description:
If this property is specified, the data that is fed to the job is expected to be pre-summarized.
This property value is the name of the field that contains the count of raw data points that have been summarized.
The same `summary_count_field_name` applies to all detectors in the job.
properties.name: summary_count_field_name

types.description:
A class that implements `OverloadOf` should have the exact same properties with the same types.
It can change if a property is required or not. There is no need to port the descriptions
and js doc tags, the compiler will do that for you.

properties.description:
The field used to split the data.
In particular, this property is used for analyzing the splits with respect to their own history.
It is used for finding unusual values in the context of the split.
properties.name: by_field_name

properties.description:
An array of custom rule objects, which enable you to customize the way detectors operate.
For example, a rule may dictate to the detector conditions under which results should be skipped.
Kibana refers to custom rules as job rules.
properties.name: custom_rules

properties.description: A description of the detector.
properties.name: detector_description

properties.description:
A unique identifier for the detector.
This identifier is based on the order of the detectors in the `analysis_config`, starting at zero.
properties.name: detector_index

properties.description:
Contains one of the following values: `all`, `none`, `by`, or `over`.
If set, frequent entities are excluded from influencing the anomaly results.
Entities can be considered frequent over time or frequent in a population.
If you are working with both over and by fields, then you can set `exclude_frequent` to all for both fields, or to `by` or `over` for those specific fields.
properties.name: exclude_frequent

properties.description:
The field that the detector uses in the function.
If you use an event rate function such as `count` or `rare`, do not specify this field.
properties.name: field_name

properties.description:
The analysis function that is used.
For example, `count`, `rare`, `mean`, `min`, `max`, and `sum`.
properties.name: function

properties.description:
The field used to split the data.
In particular, this property is used for analyzing the splits with respect to the history of all splits.
It is used for finding unusual values in the population of all splits.
properties.name: over_field_name

properties.description:
The field used to segment the analysis.
When you use this property, you have completely independent baselines for each value of this field.
properties.name: partition_field_name

properties.description: Defines whether a new series is used as the null series when there is no value for the by or partition fields.
properties.name: use_null

properties.description: Collection of preprocessors
properties.name: preprocessors

properties.description: The definition of the trained model.
properties.name: trained_model

properties.description: The definition for a binary decision tree.
properties.name: tree

properties.description:
The definition of a node in a tree.
There are two major types of nodes: leaf nodes and not-leaf nodes.
- Leaf nodes only need node_index and leaf_value defined.
- All other nodes need split_feature, left_child, right_child, threshold, decision_type, and default_left defined.
properties.name: tree_node

properties.description: The definition for an ensemble model
properties.name: ensemble

properties.description: The overall assignment state.
properties.name: assignment_state

properties.description: The allocation state for each node.
properties.name: routing_table

properties.description: The timestamp when the deployment started.
properties.name: start_time

properties.description: The size of the trained model in bytes.
properties.name: model_bytes

properties.description: The unique identifier for the trained model.
properties.name: model_id

properties.description: The unique identifier for the trained model deployment.
properties.name: deployment_id

properties.description: The size of the trained model cache.
properties.name: cache_size

properties.description: The total number of allocations this model is assigned across ML nodes.
properties.name: number_of_allocations

properties.description: Number of inference requests are allowed in the queue at a time.
properties.name: queue_capacity

properties.description: Number of threads per allocation.
properties.name: threads_per_allocation

properties.description: Limits can be applied for the resources required to hold the mathematical models in memory. These limits are approximate and can be set per job. They do not control the memory used by other processes, for example the Elasticsearch Java processes.
properties.name: model_memory_limit

properties.description: The ID of the document.
properties.name: _id

properties.description: The index of the document.
properties.name: _index

properties.description: An artificial document (a document not present in the index) for which you want to retrieve term vectors.
properties.name: doc

properties.description:
Comma-separated list or wildcard expressions of fields to include in the statistics.
Used as the default list unless a specific field list is provided in the `completion_fields` or `fielddata_fields` parameters.
properties.name: fields

properties.description: If `true`, the response includes the document count, sum of document frequencies, and sum of total term frequencies.
properties.name: field_statistics

properties.description: Filter terms based on their tf-idf scores.
properties.name: filter

properties.description: If `true`, the response includes term offsets.
properties.name: offsets

properties.description: If `true`, the response includes term payloads.
properties.name: payloads

properties.description: If `true`, the response includes term positions.
properties.name: positions

properties.description: Custom value used to route operations to a specific shard.
properties.name: routing

properties.description: If true, the response includes term frequency and document frequency.
properties.name: term_statistics

properties.description: If `true`, returns the document version as part of a hit.
properties.name: version

properties.description: Specific version type.
properties.name: version_type

properties.description:
Ignore words which occur in more than this many docs.
Defaults to unbounded.
properties.name: max_doc_freq

properties.description: Maximum number of terms that must be returned per field.
properties.name: max_num_terms

properties.description:
Ignore words with more than this frequency in the source doc.
Defaults to unbounded.
properties.name: max_term_freq

properties.description:
The maximum word length above which words will be ignored.
Defaults to unbounded.
properties.name: max_word_length

properties.description: Ignore terms which do not occur in at least this many docs.
properties.name: min_doc_freq

properties.description: Ignore words with less than this frequency in the source doc.
properties.name: min_term_freq

properties.description: The minimum word length below which words will be ignored.
properties.name: min_word_length

properties.description: Query Ruleset unique identifier
properties.name: ruleset_id

properties.description: Rules associated with the query ruleset
properties.name: rules

properties.description: Ruleset unique identifier
properties.name: ruleset_id

properties.description: The number of rules associated with this ruleset
properties.name: rule_total_count

properties.description: A map of criteria type to the number of rules of that type
properties.name: rule_criteria_types_counts

properties.description: Ruleset unique identifier
properties.name: ruleset_id

properties.description: Rule unique identifier within that ruleset
properties.name: rule_id

properties.description: The search request’s ID, used to group result details later.
properties.name: id

properties.description: The query being evaluated.
properties.name: request

properties.description: List of document ratings
properties.name: ratings

properties.description: The search template Id
properties.name: template_id

properties.description: The search template parameters.
properties.name: params

properties.description: The document ID.
properties.name: _id

properties.description: The document’s index. For data streams, this should be the document’s backing index.
properties.name: _index

properties.description: The document’s relevance with regard to this search request.
properties.name: rating

types.description: Precision at K (P@k)

properties.description: Controls how unlabeled documents in the search results are counted. If set to true, unlabeled documents are ignored and neither count as relevant or irrelevant. Set to false (the default), they are treated as irrelevant.
properties.name: ignore_unlabeled

properties.description: Sets the rating threshold above which documents are considered to be "relevant".
properties.name: relevant_rating_threshold

properties.description: Sets the maximum number of documents retrieved per query. This value will act in place of the usual size parameter in the query.
properties.name: k

types.description: Recall at K (R@k)
Mean Reciprocal Rank
Discounted cumulative gain (DCG)

properties.description: If set to true, this metric will calculate the Normalized DCG.
properties.name: normalize

types.description: Expected Reciprocal Rank (ERR)

properties.description: The highest relevance grade used in the user-supplied relevance judgments.
properties.name: maximum_relevance

properties.description: The metric_score in the details section shows the contribution of this query to the global quality metric score
properties.name: metric_score

properties.description: The unrated_docs section contains an _index and _id entry for each document in the search result for this query that didn’t have a ratings value. This can be used to ask the user to supply ratings for these documents
properties.name: unrated_docs

properties.description: The hits section shows a grouping of the search results with their supplied ratings
properties.name: hits

properties.description: The metric_details give additional information about the calculated quality metric (e.g. how many of the retrieved documents were relevant). The content varies for each metric but allows for better interpretation of the results
properties.name: metric_details

properties.description: The name of the data stream, index, or index alias you are copying to.
properties.name: index

properties.description:
Set to `create` to only index documents that do not already exist.
Important: To reindex to a data stream destination, this argument must be `create`.
properties.name: op_type

properties.description: The name of the pipeline to use.
properties.name: pipeline

properties.description:
By default, a document's routing is preserved unless it’s changed by the script.
Set to `discard` to set routing to `null`,  or `=value` to route using the specified `value`.
properties.name: routing

properties.description: The versioning to use for the indexing operation.
properties.name: version_type

properties.description:
The name of the data stream, index, or alias you are copying from.
Accepts a comma-separated list to reindex from multiple sources.
properties.name: index

properties.description: Specifies the documents to reindex using the Query DSL.
properties.name: query

properties.description: A remote instance of Elasticsearch that you want to index from.
properties.name: remote

properties.description:
The number of documents to index per batch.
Use when indexing from remote to ensure that the batches fit within the on-heap buffer, which defaults to a maximum size of 100 MB.
properties.name: size

properties.description: Slice the reindex request manually using the provided slice ID and total number of slices.
properties.name: slice

properties.description:
If `true` reindexes all source fields.
Set to a list to reindex select fields.
properties.name: _source

properties.description:
The remote connection timeout.
Defaults to 30 seconds.
properties.name: connect_timeout

properties.description: An object containing the headers of the request.
properties.name: headers

properties.description: The URL for the remote instance of Elasticsearch that you want to index from.
properties.name: host

properties.description: The username to use for authentication with the remote host.
properties.name: username

properties.description: The password to use for authentication with the remote host.
properties.name: password

properties.description: The remote socket read timeout. Defaults to 30 seconds.
properties.name: socket_timeout

properties.description: Document that’s temporarily indexed in-memory and accessible from the script.
properties.name: document

properties.description:
Index containing a mapping that’s compatible with the indexed document.
You may specify a remote index by prefixing the index with the remote cluster alias.
properties.name: index

properties.description: Use this parameter to specify a query for computing a score.
properties.name: query

properties.description: A retriever that replaces the functionality of a traditional query.

properties.description: A retriever that replaces the functionality  of a knn search.

properties.description: A retriever that replaces the functionality of a rule query.

properties.description: Defines a query to retrieve a set of top documents.

properties.description: Defines a search after object parameter used for pagination.

properties.description: Maximum number of documents to collect for each shard.

properties.description: A sort object that that specifies the order of matching documents.

properties.description: Collapses the top documents by a specified key into a single top document per key.

properties.description: Query to filter the documents that can match.

properties.description: Minimum _score for matching documents. Documents with a lower _score are not included in the top documents.

properties.description: The name of the vector field to search against.
properties.name: field

properties.description: Query vector. Must have the same number of dimensions as the vector field you are searching against. You must provide a query_vector_builder or query_vector, but not both.

properties.description: Number of nearest neighbors to return as top hits.

properties.name: retriever

properties.description: Unique identifier of the inference endpoint created using the inference API.

properties.description: The text snippet used as the basis for similarity comparison
properties.name: inference_text

properties.name: field

properties.description: This value determines the size of the individual result set.

Invalidation status for the API key.

The role descriptors assigned to this API key when it was created or last updated.
An empty role descriptor means the API key inherits the owner user’s permissions.
properties.name: role_descriptors

properties.description:
The owner user’s permissions associated with the API key.
It is a point-in-time snapshot captured at creation and subsequent updates.
An API key’s effective permissions are an intersection of its assigned privileges and the owner user’s permissions.
properties.name: limited_by

properties.description: A list of cluster privileges. These privileges define the cluster level actions that API keys are able to execute.
properties.name: cluster

properties.description: A list of indices permissions entries.
properties.name: indices

properties.name: applications

properties.name: metadata

properties.name: run_as

properties.description: Optional description of the role descriptor
properties.name: description

properties.description: The document fields that the owners of the role have read access to.
properties.name: field_security

properties.description: A list of indices (or index name patterns) to which the permissions in this entry apply.
properties.name: names

properties.description: The index level privileges that owners of the role have on the specified indices.
properties.name: privileges

properties.name: query

properties.description: The name of the application to which this entry applies.

properties.name: resources

properties.description: The name of the application.
properties.name: application

properties.description: A list of the privileges that you want to check for the specified resources. May be either application privilege names, or the names of actions that are granted by those privileges
properties.name: privileges

properties.description: A list of resource names against which the privileges should be checked
properties.name: resources

properties.description: A list of indices.
properties.name: names

properties.description: A list of the privileges that you want to check for the specified indices.
properties.name: privileges

properties.description:
This needs to be set to true (default is false) if using wildcards or regexps for patterns that cover restricted indices.
Implicitly, restricted indices do not match index patterns because restricted indices usually have limited privileges and including them in pattern tests would render most such tests false.
If restricted indices are explicitly included in the names list, privileges will be checked against them regardless of the value of allow_restricted_indices.
properties.name: allow_restricted_indices

properties.description:
Sub-aggregations for this aggregation.
Only applies to bucket aggregations.
properties.name: aggregations

properties.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that calculates an approximate count of distinct values.
properties.name: cardinality

properties.description:
A multi-bucket aggregation that creates composite buckets from different sources.
Unlike the other multi-bucket aggregations, you can use the `composite` aggregation to paginate *all* buckets from a multi-level aggregation efficiently.
properties.name: composite

properties.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation that enables the user to define a set of date ranges - each representing a bucket.
properties.name: date_range

properties.description: A single bucket aggregation that narrows the set of documents to those that match a query.
properties.name: filter

properties.description: A multi-bucket aggregation where each bucket contains the documents that match a query.
properties.name: filters

properties.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation that enables the user to define a set of ranges - each representing a bucket.
properties.name: range

properties.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation where buckets are dynamically built - one per unique value.
properties.name: terms

properties.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that counts the number of values that are extracted from the aggregated documents.
properties.name: value_count

properties.description: matches documents matching boolean combinations of other queries.
properties.name: bool

properties.description: Returns documents that contain an indexed value for a field.
properties.name: exists

properties.description:
Returns documents based on their IDs.
This query uses document IDs stored in the `_id` field.
properties.name: ids

properties.description:
Returns documents that match a provided text, number, date or boolean value.
The provided text is analyzed before matching.
properties.name: match

properties.description: Matches all documents, giving them all a `_score` of 1.0.
properties.name: match_all

properties.description: Returns documents that contain a specific prefix in a provided field.
properties.name: prefix

properties.description: Returns documents that contain terms within a provided range.
properties.name: range

properties.description: Returns documents based on a provided query string, using a parser with a limited but fault-tolerant syntax.
properties.name: simple_query_string

properties.description:
Returns documents that contain an exact term in a provided field.
To return a document, the query term must exactly match the queried field's value, including whitespace and capitalization.
properties.name: term

properties.description:
Returns documents that contain one or more exact terms in a provided field.
To return a document, one or more terms must exactly match a field value, including whitespace and capitalization.
properties.name: terms

properties.description: Returns documents that contain terms matching a wildcard pattern.
properties.name: wildcard

properties.description: Collection of queries from which to build buckets.
properties.name: filters

properties.description: Set to `true` to add a bucket to the response which will contain all documents that do not match any of the given filters.
properties.name: other_bucket

properties.description: The key with which the other bucket is returned.
properties.name: other_bucket_key

properties.description:
By default, the named filters aggregation returns the buckets as an object.
Set to `false` to return the buckets as an array of objects.
properties.name: keyed

properties.description: The security privileges that the transform uses to run its queries. If Elastic Stack security features were disabled at the time of the most recent update to the transform, this property is omitted.
properties.name: authorization

properties.description: The time the transform was created.
properties.name: create_time

properties.description: Free text description of the transform.
properties.name: description

properties.description: The destination for the transform.
properties.name: dest

properties.description: The pivot method transforms the data by aggregating and grouping it.
properties.name: pivot

properties.description: Defines optional transform settings.
properties.name: settings

properties.description: The source of the data for the transform.
properties.name: source

properties.description: Defines the properties transforms require to run continuously.
properties.name: sync

properties.description: The version of Elasticsearch that existed on the node when the transform was created.
properties.name: version

properties.description: If an API key was used for the most recent update to the transform, its name and identifier are listed in the response.
properties.name: api_key

properties.description: If a user ID was used for the most recent update to the transform, its roles at the time of the update are listed in the response.
properties.name: roles

properties.description: If a service account was used for the most recent update to the transform, the account name is listed in the response.
properties.name: service_account

properties.description: Specifies the date field that is used to identify the latest documents.
properties.name: sort

properties.description: Specifies an array of one or more fields that are used to group the data.
properties.name: unique_key

properties.description:
Defines how to aggregate the grouped data. The following aggregations are currently supported: average, bucket
script, bucket selector, cardinality, filter, geo bounds, geo centroid, geo line, max, median absolute deviation,
min, missing, percentiles, rare terms, scripted metric, stats, sum, terms, top metrics, value count, weighted
average.
properties.name: aggregations

properties.description:
Defines how to group the data. More than one grouping can be defined per pivot. The following groupings are
currently supported: date histogram, geotile grid, histogram, terms.
properties.name: group_by

properties.description: Specifies that the transform uses a time field to set the retention policy.
properties.name: time

properties.description: The date field that is used to calculate the age of the document.
properties.name: field

properties.description:
Specifies the maximum age of a document in the destination index. Documents that are older than the configured
value are removed from the destination index.
properties.name: max_age

types.description: The source of the data for the transform.

properties.description:
Specifies whether the transform checkpoint ranges should be optimized for performance. Such optimization can align
checkpoint ranges with the date histogram interval when date histogram is specified as a group source in the
transform config. As a result, less document updates in the destination index will be performed thus improving
overall performance.
properties.name: align_checkpoints

properties.description:
Defines if dates in the ouput should be written as ISO formatted string or as millis since epoch. epoch_millis was
the default for transforms created before version 7.11. For compatible output set this value to `true`.
properties.name: dates_as_epoch_millis

properties.description: Specifies whether the transform should deduce the destination index mappings from the transform configuration.
properties.name: deduce_mappings

properties.description:
Specifies a limit on the number of input documents per second. This setting throttles the transform by adding a
wait time between search requests. The default value is null, which disables throttling.
properties.name: docs_per_second

properties.description:
Defines the initial page size to use for the composite aggregation for each checkpoint. If circuit breaker
exceptions occur, the page size is dynamically adjusted to a lower value. The minimum value is `10` and the
maximum is `65,536`.
properties.name: max_page_search_size

properties.description:
If `true`, the transform runs in unattended mode. In unattended mode, the transform retries indefinitely in case
of an error which means the transform never fails. Setting the number of retries other than infinite fails in
validation.
properties.name: unattended

properties.description:
The source indices for the transform. It can be a single index, an index pattern (for example, `"my-index-*""`), an
array of indices (for example, `["my-index-000001", "my-index-000002"]`), or an array of index patterns (for
example, `["my-index-*", "my-other-index-*"]`. For remote indices use the syntax `"remote_name:index_name"`. If
any indices are in remote clusters then the master node and at least one transform node must have the `remote_cluster_client` node role.
properties.name: index

properties.description: A query clause that retrieves a subset of data from the source index.
properties.name: query

properties.description:
Definitions of search-time runtime fields that can be used by the transform. For search runtime fields all data
nodes, including remote nodes, must be 7.12 or later.
properties.name: runtime_mappings

properties.description: Specifies that the transform uses a time field to synchronize the source and destination indices.
properties.name: time

properties.description: The time delay between the current time and the latest input data time.
properties.name: delay

properties.description:
The date field that is used to identify new documents in the source. In general, it’s a good idea to use a field
that contains the ingest timestamp. If you use a different field, you might need to set the delay such that it
accounts for data transmission delays.
properties.name: field

properties.description:
The destination index for the transform. The mappings of the destination index are deduced based on the source
fields when possible. If alternate mappings are required, use the create index API prior to starting the
transform.
properties.name: index

properties.description: The unique identifier for an ingest pipeline.
properties.name: pipeline
